newsitem.title: USA: N.J. governor signs $230 mln bonds for dredging.
newsitem.headline: N.J. governor signs $230 mln bonds for dredging.

text.p: New Jersey Gov. Christine Whitman signed legislation Thursday implementing a $230 million bond act for port dredging approved by voters last year.

With cargo containers at Port Newark being unloaded in the background, Whitman said the money would be used to keep the ports open and generating what she said was $29 billion in economic activity for the state.
Whitman the state bond money would preserve 18,000 jobs and "preserve New Jersey's reputation as an international gateway."
But the governor said she was worried that the federal government had not included enough funding for port dredging in its budget request, in particular for Elizabeth Channel.

"The Elizabeth Channel needs immediate attention," Whitman said. "But the federal government may not be ready to fund this work as soon as permits are issued. If that's the case, I will ask the Port Authority to draw on the $65 million in dredging funds allocated to New Jersey to dredge the Channel."
Whitman also said she had asked for a review of potential sites to dump dredged material, with a report due back in six months.

The bond authorization includes $185 million to dredge navigational channels that lead to port areas known as Reaches A, B, C and D in the Port Authority's region. That bond money would also finance the search for appropriate disposal sites.

Another $20 million would be used to dredge navigational channels located in the rest of the state, and $20 million more would be used to finance economic development projects in the Delaware River and Bay region.
The last $5 million is earmarked for decontamination technology.
The bond money is in addition to $130 million the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey already designated for dredging.
